data.title: Linux update flow is not very user friendly
data.body:
When I start my Code on Linux I always get the notification that an update is available but that notification just points me to the general download location, not the right build for my update channel.

Can we not just download the right RPM/DEB package in the background and open it using the package manager, similar to how we do it on windows with the installer?

/cc @joaomoreno

data.title: Editor Action Format hotkey not working on some jsx markup
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.1
- OS Version:Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create .tsx file with simple jsx template (one div element).
2. Add a text with double quotes and put inside it a some substitution (with braces).
3. Press shift+alt+f to perform a format action.

After that formatting will not work on any file of project until vsc restarted.

My example.tsx:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8034149/15717614/d62dbcec-2838-11e6-8b07-81779741b6a0.png)

data.title: View > Toggle Output, Debug Console and Integrated Terminal are missing on alpha
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.2.0-alpha
- OS Version:Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open the View menu
2. The block with Toggle Output, Toggle Debug Console and Toggle Integrated Terminal are missing.

Might be due to refactoring with https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/commit/207a8e33145c09aaeaa99e44ee7599a4112cfbd4#diff-cfab7992ca96cfc46d55c980e3225116

data.title: Mouse word selection is strange when non-word character is at the end of line
data.body:
![bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22350/15716128/63cdcc9e-2821-11e6-9ac2-f431df56f1d8.gif)

Have a buffer with a few consecutive lines ending in a non alphabetic character, like:

```
before.a
before
hello:
there:
this is strange:
here
it
is
```

Using the mouse, **double click** at the end of one of those lines, drag up and down through the end of the other lines that end with a non alphabetic character. Selection only starts when a line which doesn't end in a non alphabetic character comes along.

data.title: Markdown Syntax Highlighting - Opening Literal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Linux Mint LMDE 2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create new markdown file.  Type in: 

```
The TeX command `\TeX` is fun! So is `\LaTeX`!
```

Problem:
In markdown ``\` doesn't appear to be registered as an opening code literal for syntax highlighting.
Code will highlight this as shown:

![markdownhilight](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12069845/15714738/5fb205fc-27e1-11e6-941f-1321f3035f75.png)

I was looking into possibly fixing this, but I found this statement

> some of VS Code's built-in colorizers (e.g. Markdown) are integrated differently and cannot be overridden.

here https://code.visualstudio.com/Docs/customization/colorizer.  So I didn't know where to look really.

data.title: crtl+mouseUp or ctrl+mouseDown text size
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce: N/A

Right now there is no binding to the crtl+mouseWheel is VS and in a lot of tools that combination would increase the text size. I understand there is a crtl+= and crtl+- which zooms in but that zooms everything in including the panel on the left. It would be nice to have a shortcut to just increase the font size

data.title: TypeScript should revalidate all files that were open in an editor.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: alpha

Since we are now disposing models more aggressively we should revalidate all files that were open in an editor. Otherwise the error count will become very unstable.

data.title: Add Better integration between PowerShell Extention Terminal Session and New Integrated Terminal.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

These should be able to share the same session, but first #7095 likely needs to be addresses since the PowerShell Extension uses a 64 bit session.

The Latest Version of the PowerShell Extension added a new Profile `Microsoft.VSCode_profile.ps1` for use in the PowerShell Extension session, it would be beneficial if the Code Terminal could also use this profile. Right now the editor is using the default console profile `Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1`

There are a lot of great new features in the PowerShell Extension for interacting with the editor environment, and it would be beneficial to be able to take advantage of these in the integrated terminal.

data.title: Use 64 Bit Terminals on 64 WIndows
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. The terminal opened by default is the 32bit terminal for cmd.exe or Powershell.exe
2. On 64 Bit OS Code should be interacting with the sysnative variants.

There is a sort of work around by adding the sysnative path like below, but this should be handled by default. The PowerShell Extension does this for it's terminal session.

``` json
{
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\WINDOWS\\sysnative\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe"
}
```

Using 32bit breaks a lot of modules and also causes issues when testing your code. PSReadLine is an example of one Module that breaks. One example that could cause problems in your code, is if you are testing something with parts of the registry, the 32 bit console is going to give you bad results since it will be giving you results for the wow3264Node instead.

data.title: Snippet with multiple variable refs is not completing properly, leaving multiple cursors in editor.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a snippet, but do not enter a `$0` to explicitly tell the snippet where to put the cursor after the completion of the snippet.

```
    "log error": {
        "prefix": "logerror",
        "body": [
            "logger.error({ logContext: lc, errorContext: `${1:err}`, error: $1 });"
        ],
        "description": "Log error message."
    }
```
1. Invoke the snippet. Enter a default value (Issue #7093 has been created for the default value not already being prepopulated in the second variable reference). Notice that there are multiple cursors when entering this value, which is as it should be.
2. Press enter to complete the snippet.

What should happen: The snippet should exit and there should only be one cursor in the editor.
What actually happens: The snippet leaves two active cursors in the editor.

You can press `esc` and the snippet will complete properly. You can also enter a `$0` in the snippet such as:

```
    "log error": {
        "prefix": "logerror",
        "body": [
            "logger.error({ logContext: lc, errorContext: `${1:err}`, error: $1 });$0"
        ],
        "description": "Log error message."
    }
```

And the snippet will complete properly. But if you do not explicitly state this `$0` marker, it does not act as the TextMate documentation states: 

> If you do not explicitly set $0, the caret will be at the end of the snippet.

data.title: Snippet default value is only populated for first variable reference
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Do a snippet with a default value and multiple locations. E.g.

```
    "log error": {
        "prefix": "logerror",
        "body": [
            "logger.error({ logContext: lc, errorContext: `${1:err}`, error: $1 });"
        ],
        "description": "Log error message."
    }
```
1. Invoke the snippet. 
   We should see:

```
logger.error({ logContext: lc, errorContext: `err`, error: err });
```

...but we actually see

```
logger.error({ logContext: lc, errorContext: `err`, error:  });
```

So, we are only seeing the default value at the first variable's reference. It should be at both locations with the default value. If we type anything in, then the second variable reference will update as expected. It just doesn't start out with it without typing anything.

data.title: Better behavior of the autoClosingBrackets-Feature for quotation marks

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows Server 2008 R2

As discussed in issue #327, the `autoClosingBrackets` option has some edge cases where it does not speed up typing but actually increases the work necessary. One of these cases is when I try to replace quotation marks as start and end character of strings.

Steps to Reproduce: 
1. Open a TypeScript file
2. Select a single quoation mark (')
3. Trying to replace it with double quotation marks (") leads to a a single quotation mark wrapped in double quotation marks (" ' "; I added the spaces to make it more readable)

The same issue occurs when I use the grave accent to replace double quotation marks. It would be great if VS Code could detect the intention and overwrite the selected character or replace the start and end chartacter of the string (e.g. 'Hello World' becomes "Hello World" or `Hello World` based on the new character).

data.title: run all tasks with `isBuildCommand` flag set on build (all isTestCommand on test)
data.body:
- VSCode Version:   1.1.1

Currently the first task with the `isBuildCommand: true` is run as the build command regardless of other tasks with the same flag. It would be a great help if all of them are run in the order of declaration.

data.title: need some visual feedback when the task is done
data.body: Currently there is no way to tell if a script is running other than a spinning bar in the bottom which is hard to see. If the task doesn't spit any output than there is no way to know if it's still running or finished other than by looking at that bar. Would be nice to get something more visible and explicit.

data.title: Terminal: pressing Escape closes the terminal panel
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0 Insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. open the terminal panel
2. type some text
3. press Escape

What happens: the text is removed (that's expected), and the terminal panel is immediately closed (unexpected).

data.title: Open applicationHost.config with code, the file appears to be empty, even if it is not

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 8.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Navigate to path C:\Windows\System32\inetsrv\config
2. opening config folder will ask for your permission, give it
3. open applicationHost.config
4. in Code, the file looks to be empty, event if it is not. opening it with Notepad++ works.
5. Running code as administrator + drag & drop the file gives and error "the path ... does not seem to exist anymore on disk"
6. I tried using Visual Studio 2015 Update 2 to open it, but I cannot. It does not appear in "Open File Dialog"

data.title: Debug popovers do not work for class' fields/properties
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5

When debugging a unity project, debug popovers do not seem to be working for a class' fields/properties, but do work for local variables:

Hovering over the local variable `schedule` correctly shows its value:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1172479/15700510/9760d532-27aa-11e6-9308-cd8a61921d43.png)

Hovering over the private field `data` does nothing, but it's values do appear on the left panel:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1172479/15700567/fdd69b62-27aa-11e6-8d19-055cf00ef430.png)

Sorry if duplicate!

data.title: paths.normalize(): perf regression
data.body:
Running the following test with profiling enabled shows that recent changes to paths.ts cause a major performance regression:
- open the monaco folder
- expand some folders
- click refresh 10 times

Before:

After:

data.title: Drop "visual-studio-" from packages names so they match command names
Add support for JSDoc's @inheritDoc for TypeScript
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insider
- OS Version: Win 10

For TypeScript, for instance when a class implements an interface, it would be good if the IntelliSense would recognize JSDoc's `@inheritDoc` and display the JSDoc declared at the parent/interface level instead.

http://usejsdoc.org/tags-inheritdoc.html

data.title: Option to auto-pin all
data.body:
I would like to have an option to auto-pin every editor.
An alternative naming is to disable preview tab.

My workflow is that I am used to having all the editors I navigate between in my history. I believe some of our users use it in the same way and with the june changes we might break their mental model.
Due to that we should introduce this setting such that we behave as before - nothing is preview, everything is pinned.

data.title: User settings are not overriding on mac
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1.1
- OS Version: Mac OS X

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Added following setting for indent with 2 spaces
   "editor.insertSpaces": true,
   "editor.tabSize": 2
2. Editor still formatting with 4 spaces.

data.title: rpm versioning
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.1
- OS Version: Linux rpm 

Steps to Reproduce:

rpm is called vscode-x86_64.rpm

when installing the package is called
code-1.1.1-1463146452

normal convention would be to have the rpm name be the -same- as the package name that's installed and to also add a distribution version in it (el6, el7,...)
so for rhel,centos,ol,scientific Linux,... 

it should be  
download code-1.1.1-146314652.el7.x86_64.rpm and install code-1.1.1-146314652 or
download vscode-1.1.1-146314652.el7.x86_64.rpm and instal vscode-1.1.1-146314652

data.title: upgrading installed 1.0 rpm to 1.1 removes /usr/bin/code and doesn't add a new symlink after upgrade.
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

Steps to Reproduce:

First problem : 

[root@ol6 ~]# ls /usr/bin/code
ls: cannot access /usr/bin/code: No such file or directory
[root@ol6 ~]# #install 1.0
[root@ol6 ~]# rpm -ivh /home/wcoekaer/Downloads/vscode-x86_64.rpm
Preparing...                          ################################# [100%]
Updating / installing...
   1:code-1.0.0-1460557031            ################################# [100%]
[root@ol6 ~]# ls /usr/bin/code
/usr/bin/code
[root@ol6 ~]# #upgrade to 1.1
[root@ol6 ~]# rpm -Uvh /root/Downloads/vscode-x86_64.rpm
Preparing...                          ################################# [100%]
Updating / installing...
   1:code-1.1.1-1463146452            ################################# [ 50%]
Cleaning up / removing...
   2:code-1.0.0-1460557031            ################################# [100%]
**[root@ol6 ~]# ls /usr/bin/code
ls: cannot access /usr/bin/code: No such file or directory**

second problem :

when I install 1.1 from scratch 

[root@ol6 ~]# rpm -ivh /root/Downloads/vscode-x86_64.rpm
Preparing...                          ################################# [100%]
Updating / installing...
   1:code-1.1.1-1463146452            ################################# [100%]
[root@ol6 ~]# ls /usr/bin/code
/usr/bin/code
[root@ol6 ~]# rpm -e code
[root@ol6 ~]# ls /usr/bin/code
/usr/bin/code

it did not remove the symlink /usr/bin/code.

data.title: scriptable terminal
data.body:
feature request: since the build system is kinda useless when build steps require multiple commands, being able to send commands to the integrated terminal from script.

my personal reason for this is that for skyrim modding, its a multiple step build system which requires the editor being wrapped by MO so that the app has access to the virtual directory. executing a batch script is out of the question as the commands need to be dynamically generated, plus the build system currently seems to spawn outside of the wrapped process.

data.title: VSCode overlays everything even when minimized on Ubuntu

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.0 and 1.1.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 x64 running in a VirtualBox on Windows 10 Pro x64 (3D acceleration enabled)

Steps to Reproduce:

Open VS Code and Minimize it or simply try to drag another window over it
While the window handle dissappears, the UI of Code will overlay everything else.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/15688503/ad7ee9e2-277a-11e6-8bf3-8f3557b0db06.png)

Even on the lockscreen:

![unbenannt](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10532611/15688837/5d4da542-277c-11e6-99fa-f9d86888efd4.PNG)

This does not happen with 3D acceleration disabled, but disabling that also makes Ubuntu lag incredibly :/

data.title: Terminal key combinations not working properly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open terminal using sysnative Powershell as default
2. Press key combinations like the following and it inputs the key mapping instead:
   - <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>c</kbd> produces ^C
   - <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>left</kbd> produces 5D
   - <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd> produces 5C
3. Using Shift combinations does not highlight text
   - <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>end</kbd> Skips to end without highlight
   - <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>home</kbd>  Skips to beginning without highlight
   - <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>left</kbd>  moves left without highlight
   - <kbd>shift</kbd> + <kbd>right</kbd>  moves right without highlight

data.title: Allow to print the editor contents

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1
- OS Version: Win10

Please,
Can you add the print command

data.title: When not in a folder File-N/Ctrl-N creates a new file but Command palette-new file displays "Open a folder first to create files or folders within."
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.1.1
- OS Version: Windows 7 Enterprise

I always keep a VS Code window open for creating random one off snippets of code that I never save. If i have something larger in one file I like to create a new temporary file and use it. I have always used the command palette to do this but since updating VSCode it no longer works. Instead I get an info-bar that says `Open a folder first to create files or folders within.`

Was this functionality intentionally restricted? If so, why? It seemed to work perfectly fine before.

data.title: [Feature request] Show errors/warnings in 'pinnable' panel
data.body:
Due to this issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/7033

I would like to have a pinnable error/warnings dialog on the bottom/top/whatever side.

Thank you for not moving this feature request to 2017 :-)
